awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Academic Success and Professional Development (ASAP) Project-Based Engineering Excellence Transfer Academy Across Arizona
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation (NSF) Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project is a collaborative effort between Arizona State University, Central Arizona College, Cochise College, Eastern Arizona College, Estrella Mountain Community College, Glendale Community College, Mesa Community College, Mohave Community College, Phoenix College, and Yavapai College. The program will provide scholarships for talented, low-income students with demonstrated financial need who are pursuing degrees in engineering or computer science. In addition to scholarships, the program will provide academic and other support to increase the persistence of these academically talented, low-income students.  The project design includes an academic success and professional development course along with project-based activities.  Faculty and industrial mentors help students to envision the potential career opportunities and benefits available in engineering and computer science. Nine of the ten collaborating schools are classified as Hispanic Serving Institutions. Scholarships and support for low-income and academically talented students, who may not otherwise be able to obtain engineering or computer science degrees will help to produce a well-trained workforce that will contribute to the economic well being of the nation.

The project seeks to address the need to expand the engineering and computer science workforce by increasing the success of Arizona State University students including students that transfer from community colleges. The program combines a network of engineering mentors with a successful student-centered and mentor-driven academic success and professional development course to significantly increase the number of community college students that consider, choose, continue and graduate with a bachelor of science in engineering or computer science.  At the center of the proposed initiative is a commitment to involving students in career-shaping projects that will permit them to discover, nurture, and fully develop their technical interests. Guided by grounded theory and social cognitive career theory, the project will also study the factors most central to maintaining effectiveness while scaling up a successful student-centered and mentor-intensive transfer student support system to encompass a larger group of collaborating institutions. Community colleges will play an increasingly important role in educating the nation's engineers. This statewide project will serve as a collaborative model for four-year and two-year schools across the nation. This research will provide knowledge helpful in establishing a transfer student support program in Arizona and will inform other university and community college networks in other parts of the United States. The findings from the program will be disseminated widely to the engineering and computer science education community.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF S-STEM grant is the best of funding to directly support and motivate our academically talented Engineering and Computer Science students who also have an unmet financial need.  This funding has been instrumental in making program connections with Fort Huachuca Army Base, the largest employer in southeastern Arizona, and other tech companies in Tucson, Arizona, through field trips and job internships.  Without this funding, Cochise College would not have been able to invest in these students, and the engineering and computer science academic programs would not have been able to grow.

Over the past 6 years, 38 students were provided scholarships.  Before the grant, there was little mentoring and support provided by the college. The combined engineering and computer science graduates was only 5 in 2015 and under the grant in 2019 there were 18 graduates.  There has been a significant increase in student participation and graduation rates during the grant's support. By creating an atmosphere of inclusion, students were able to learn how to use college resources, what it takes to be successful in engineering and how to successfully navigate the university system transfer.  Parents were always welcome and appreciated the investment in their students.  In 2022, two students from the first S-STEM 2017 cohort graduated from state institutions, ASU and UA in engineering! Both students continued engaging in research during their time at the university.

One of the most exciting opportunities that all of the students were encouraged to participate in was the NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU).  Besides learning about research, REUs provided money for school without the expense of housing,and many students used the summer money to fund their academic programs at the university. Students were more likely to continue at the university, learn how to conduct research, and develop friendships with others students and faculty from across the country.  REUs are one of the most powerful mentoring tools in recruiting and retaining students.

Because of the funding, employers were interested in how they could assist students and support these acadmically talented students.  Fort Huachuca's Environmental Proving Ground welcomed our students and developed internship programs tailored for our students. Companies opened their doors for tours as these students learned more what an engineer actually does in day to day activities. Many companies hired our students in internships and jobs. The NSF S-STEM investment in students made an impact on employers and the community.

Although the partnership with ASU and Dr. Rodriguez, S-STEM PI and faculty at ASU, was already strong, the partnership has expanded to other departments and strengthened among the community colleges.  ASU's DOE Industrial Assessment Center (IAC) is seeking funding for an extension at Cochise College.  ASU funds paid summer internships to train our students how to conduct energy assessments.  As grant opportunities become available, ASU includes Cochise in developing partnerships with universities across the country. Phoenix College provided training for CURES and Cochise is developing a collaborative project with Phoenix College and our Science Department.  Although Cochise is a very rural college bordering Mexico, these collaborative efforts provide more opportunities for our students and faculty. These university and college collaborative opportunities would not have been initiated without the S-STEM funding.

Cochise College is appreciative of the funding.  By increasing the number of engineering scholars, the college is able to hire the students as highly qualified peer tutors filling a need at the college. Dr. Verlyn Fick, Provost, presented research to our governing board that reflected engineering students were the most likely students to transfer and graduate from a university. Although Covid impacted student lives, the college especially appreciated the opportunity to alter our budget offering more scholarships to students for a 6th year.  The NSF S-STEM grant is the best of funding that directly supports academically talented students with an unmet need.

 


Last Modified: 01/24/2023
Modified by: Celia Jenkins
